awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Use of British Slave Trade Ships to Gather Biological Specimens and Data
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

The legacy of slavery and the slave trade is an important topic for understanding modern cultures. Literature about their legacy typically focus only on social and economic impacts without considering intellectual and scientific consequences. The proposed study will examine these consequences by focusing on the transatlantic, British-dominated, slave trade in the eighteenth century. During this period, British naturalists recruited slave ship surgeons and captains to gather insects, plants, shells, and other specimens in West Africa and in American ports of slave transfer points enabling the collection of specimens from regions typically off-limits to them. This project will explore how the circulation of objects, ideas, and individuals through the networks of the slave trade engendered new scientific knowledge. To do so, it will examine scientific treatises and correspondence, institutional records of slaving companies, personal correspondence, and the records of the Royal Society to tell the stories of British slaving and science largely absent from existing scholarship. By examining the entangled histories of science and the slave trade, this project encourages broader discussions about issues of race, colonialism, science, and the ethical implications of scientific practices. The eventual outcome of this research will be a book aimed at a wide audience, including the general public and historians, as well as science and cultural studies scholars. 

Technical Summary 

Scholars all too often overlook the interdependency between science and slavery. And, most importantly, minimal research has been done on how scientists exploited the slave trade to produce new natural knowledge. This project argues that the networks of the transatlantic slave trade should be understood as a space of natural history and, like all localities of science, the social and material contexts of that space shaped and were shaped by the natural knowledge produced within it. The project also offers a new way to understand a classic question in the literature of the slave trade. For seventy years, slave trade scholars have debated the profitability of the trade and its role in Britain's economic development and industrialization. This project suggests that the debate has been too narrowly framed. To fully understand how Europeans profited from the slave trade, we must include collections of rare specimens and the scientific knowledge that resulted from their study among slaving profits.

por.por_cntn:
This grant project, “Exploring the Use of British Slave Trade Ships to Gather Biological Specimens and Data,” investigated the deep, yet often overlooked, connections between the history of science and the history of the British slave trade. It explored how British naturalists used the slave trade to collect specimens and observations of the natural world in the long eighteenth century, when the British dominated the transatlantic slave trade.

In their own ways, science and the slave trade were deeply transformative forces that laid the groundwork for the creation of the modern world.  While each has been the subject of innovative and important scholarship, the two have very rarely been examined together. This project was the first full-length historical study to examine the intersection of the history of science and slaving. For decades, scholars have debated the extent to which profits from the slave trade underwrote Britain’s economic development and industrialization. Yet this project demonstrates that these debates have been too narrowly framed. To fully understand how Europeans profited from the slave trade, we must include collections of rare specimens, observations of distant flora and fauna, and the scientific knowledge that was produced as a result among the profits of the trade.

The work resulting from this project revealed how British scientists exploited the routes and personnel of the slave trade to gain access to specimens from far-off regions such as Spanish America, West Africa, and the Caribbean. For instance, naturalists who rarely left London recruited slave ship captains, ship surgeons, and other mariners to gather plants, shells, insects, and other natural historical specimens from slaving ports in West Africa and from American ports where captive Africans were disembarked and sold. The slave trade provided access to regions otherwise off-limits to British naturalists. For example, employees of the British South Sea Company, which held the monopoly on the legal slave trade to Spanish America from 1713 to 1739, were some of the only Britons allowed to visit Spanish ports such as Vera Cruz and Porto Bello. Yet, some of the flora and fauna British naturalists most wished to study were indigenous to regions within Spain’s American territories. This project demonstrated that the particularities of the British slave trade shaped the knowledge produced through its networks and that scientific knowledge, in turn, influenced the development of the slave trade.

This project enabled archival, manuscript, material cultural, and rare book research in museums, libraries, and archives on both sides of the Atlantic. The PI conducted research using materials from repositories in Great Britain, Spain, Sweden, and the United States, including the British Library, the British National Archives, the Natural History Museum in London, the Biblioteca Nacional de España, the University of Uppsala, the Oxford Natural History Museum, the Department of Plant Sciences at Oxford University, Special Collections at the University of Glasgow, and the Huntington Library in San Marino, California.

Project outcomes also included the presentation of this work at more than half dozen conferences and universities. These included invited talks at the University of Cambridge, Queen Mary’s University of London, and UCLA. They also included presentations at conferences and workshops sponsored by the University of California, Irvine; the Linnean Society of London; the Society of Early Americans; and the University of California, Santa Cruz.  Two peer reviewed publications have already appeared in print and another is in progress with an expected publication date of 2019. The most significant outcome of this project is the drafting of six body chapters for a planned book project, provisionally entitled Collecting Slave Traders.
